intro: Acetosella parvifolia, commonly known as the small-leaved sorrel, is a low-growing perennial plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Geraniaceae and is characterized by its rosette of serrated, lobed leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in spring, typically from April to June. It thrives in moist, acidic soils and is often found in woodland areas or along stream banks. Acetosella parvifolia is known for its edible leaves, which have a tangy, sour flavor similar to other sorrel species.
